Internet SETTLE REQUIREMENTS
This document defines common terminology and the requirements for identifying, validating, and establishing secure connections with local network devices.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Unencrypted communications have been historically designed for servers on local networks such as printers, routers, and SMB file sharing servers. However, with the advent of HTTPS everywhere, browsers disadvantage unencrypted communications by requiring a secure context for features such as Service Workers, Web Bluetooth, WebCrypto, WebTransport, and more. This increases the importance of a secure context to local domains. Non-HTTP protocols such as SMB3 encrypted file sharing would benefit from stronger server authentication and printing (IPP over HTTPS) would benefit from encrypted communications.

Existing deployments of TLS and other encrypted protocols on local networks typically make use of so-called "self-signed" X.509 certificates which lack the endorsement of a trusted third-party. In addition, network devices are unable to determine the trustworthiness of the local network, humorous solutions such as the "evil bit" from "The Security Flag in the IPv4 Header" aside.
This document defines common terminology and the requirements for identifying, validating, and establishing secure connections with local network devices.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in "Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels".
